awd_titl_txt: Workshop on Buddhism and Comparative Constitutional Law: Chicago, IL Fall 2019
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposed workshop promises to open up a new subfield in comparative constitutional studies. There is a large and rich literature on the relationship between Islam and constitutionalism, and an older historical literature on the central place of Canon law in the Western legal tradition. Writing on Buddhist law is scarce in general, and especially so with regard to constitutional thought. This is particularly problematic when Buddhist actors are playing an important role in the constitutional politics of many countries. To date, policy analysis and scholarship has not fully grappled with the growing importance of Buddhist actors and institutions on the practice, conceptualization and formation of constitutional law. This workshop and its outputs will therefore help inform policy understandings of the interaction of these two major forces in years to come. 

This workshop will produce publications and collaborations, supporting new researchers and identifying a clear research agenda for studying Buddhism and public law both within the academy and the policy community. Co-chaired by two scholars with complementary training and expertise--in political and comparative approaches to constitutional law and historical and social scientific study of Buddhism, respectively--it will consist of six panels, bringing together scholars of law and socio-legal studies with scholars of politics, history and religion, including graduate students and early-career scholars. Panelists will produce original research on Buddhism and constitutional law in particular Asian jurisdictions, while also reflecting from comparative perspectives, including international law, American and Asian constitutional law, and other traditions of religious law (Hindu law, Islamic law, Canon law).  One panel will place contemporary constitutional practice and politics in a longer span of pre-nineteenth-century Asian history, grounding discussions of the constitutional present in the region's rich historical settings. The workshop will produce an edited volume in a prominent series and a journal section, while also supporting graduate student mentoring and informing policy-making.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project aimed to convene scholars from several disciplines to identify and develop an emerging subfield, Buddhism and Comparative Constitutional Law. By examining a set of cases in historical and contemporary Asia, the project tracked patterns of mutual influence in the interactions of constitutional and Buddhist traditions. In some cases, it showed how modern constitutional form was impacted by religious idiom; in others it showed how Buddhist actors internalized constitutional language and practice to restructure internal operations.

The project was collective, inductive and socio-legal.  While many of the scholars had worked on relevant issues in particular jurisdictions, most had never met with each other, or tackled their topics in a comparative framework. We thus created the seeds of a new scholarly community. The socio-legal approach meant that we were not seeking to articulate a normative position favoring Buddhist approaches, but instead seeking to understand the interaction of Buddhism and constitutional law as it actually operates in Asia.  The inductive approach meant that we did not impose an intellectual framework, but allowed one to emerge from the data.

The project was also comparative, both across Buddhist jurisdictions and vis-a-vis other traditions. We included scholars working on Canon law, Islamic law, and the Hindu tradition, and they provided helpful points of comparison in reflecting on the chapter presentations. One of the patterns that emerged was the range of different approaches to the relationship of temporal and religious authority in different parts of Asia, corresponding to the three major Buddhist sub traditions. The Vajrajana countries in the Tibetan tradition tended to have a strong role for Buddhist actors in government, exemplified by the theocracy of Tibet. Theravada countries in Southeast Asia had more complex relations, with monarchic authority seeking to draw on and sometimes coopt the Buddhist sangha.  Northeast Asian countries had much less of a role for Buddhist actors in government, reflecting the less institutionalized and more decentralized patterns of monastic power.

The major output from the project was an edited volume published by Cambridge University Press, which has now been downloaded more than 10,000 times in less than a year. We have presented the work in 11 different countries.
